folder: Amsterdam Avenue & 113th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Old De Peyster Mansion, sold in 1892 to St. Luke's Hospital, Amsterdam Avenue, west side, at 113th Street About 1880.

Henry Lowe, owner, lived here from 1842-1892, when he sold it.

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Amsterdam Avenue, east side, between Cathedral Parkway and 113th Street, showing, in numerous views, the construction of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, extending over a number of years from 1894 to 1910. The collection consists of 638 individual pictures mounted on 312 mounts. In the main the collection is arranged chronologically.

Note by Mr. Albert Norman: This count was made after the photographs were mounted. They add up to 638 individual pictures on 312 mounts. Done June 3, 1941.

Note: For some data of the inception of the cathedral see "The New York Times, November 22, 1941."
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th St., Manhattan, NY
text:
CATHEDRAL NAVE TO RISE ON THESE FOUNDATIONS.

Bishop Manning announced on Sunday, Oct. 19, 1924 that contractors have been asked to bid on the Nave of the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, 119th Street and Amsterdam Ave. New York. The foundations, shown in the photographs, are already complete. The Nave will be 225 feet long, and the cost is estimated at between $5,000,000 and $6,000,000. The temporary wall at the eastern end of the Nave foundation will be torn out when the Nave is built, so that Nave and crossing will join.

The portion of the Cathedral here shown-the crossing with the choir in black- was completed in 1921. The Nave's width will be 132 feet and the height of the interior is to be 130 feet. Transcripts to be erected at each side of the crossing will make the total width of the Cathedral 315 feet.

from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th St.

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th St., Manhattan, NY
text:
Construction on New York's great cathedral to be resumed soon.

New photo of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, on which construction is to be resumed soon. This photo shows the apse, or East end, with seven radiating chapels; and the crossing, with its temporary dome.

The nave, or staff of the cross, which this completed church will form, is the next part to be built. It is also planned to erect a great tower, 500 feet high, above the present, temporary dome.

March 10, 1924  Underwood and Underwood

Even in its unfinished condition the Cathedral represents an expenditure of more than $5,000,000 and when completed will have cost four times as much. There will be seats for 7,000 persons. Some of the seven chapels are as commodious as many churches. It is expected that the Cathedral will be completed within ten years.

Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th St.

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
OLD WORLD GRANDEUR IN NEW WORLD CATHEDRALS. CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE.

New York--- the ambulatory of the Cathedral. This is a passage about twenty feet wide which runs completely around the choir and gives access to the seven chapels of tongues. At the left the photo shows the tomb of the founder of the Cathedral, Bishop Horatio Potter; sixth Bishop of New York. Its Position, immediately behind the altar is that traditionally reserved for the founder of a cathedral. It was designed by in the English Gothic style of the Fifteenth Century after studies of the tomb of Edward the Confessor, in Westminster Abbey. The photo was taken from the doorway of the Chapel of St. Martin of Tours. In the distance is the wrought iron screen before the chapel of Saint Columba and beyond that the screen before the chapel of St. Boniface is invisible.
Dec. 2, 1924

International Newsreel
from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
THE FRONT OF THE CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE With its twin towers, Rose window, and five entrances.
Feb. 1925
from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
THE CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE AS IT WILL APPEAR WHEN COMPLETED

The apse at left and the central portion under the proposed tower are already in place (???), and the foundation has been laid for the nave occupying the right half of our picture. The whole structure will be 600 feet long, and the spire 500 feet high. It will be larger in every way than St.. Paul's or Westminster Abbey, in London, or the great Cathedrals at Winchester and York. It will be exceeded in size only by St. Peter's in Rome and the Cathedral of Seville in Spain. The Cathedral although incorporated a half century ago is only one-third completed today. Approximately $15,000,000 more will be spent on it.

Feb. 1925

American Photo Service, Inc. from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th St., Manhattan, NY
text:
THE CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE AS IT APPEARS TODAY

This is a view looking toward the west. It shows especially well the chapels which half surround the Choir. Present plans call for materially increasing the height of this portion of the Cathedral.
Feb. 1925
from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th St.

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
'CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE. ONE OF THE SEVEN CHAPELS WHICH EXTEND IN A SEMI-CIRCLE AROUND THE CHOIR.

The Cathedral scheme embraces the holding of religious services in many different languages. Our picture shows the Holland Chapel, named for St. Boniface and representing the German rite. It was completed in 1916. All the chapels are Memorials. This chapel is seen through screen from sanctuary.
Feb. 1925
from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
INTERIOR OF THE CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE AS NOW IN USE.

This shows the choir and altar, and a portion of the crossing. The eight massive pillars around the altar are of Maine granite 54 feet high, each composed of only two pieces. Present plans call for replacing the semi-dome with a much higher structural roof. There would thus be another series of windows, 120 feet from the floor.

Interior of the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, looking east toward the High Altar. The photograph shows the great pillars which stand about the Sanctuary.

Feb. 1925

The Review of Reviews.
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

folder: Amsterdam Avenue & Cathedral Parkway & 113th St., Manhattan, NY
text:
THE VAST NAVE OF THE CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE NOW UNDER CONSTRUCTION.

It seems only a short time since the cornerstone of the Cathedral nave was set in place with due ceremonies. The vast structure is rising rapidly, and now adds one more to the edifices that make Morningside Heights and educational and religious center typifying the higher interests of the metropolis.
May 1926
from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th St.
